gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Snow and Ice Data Center

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Abrupt Change in Atmospheric CO2 During the Last Ice Age

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: School of Earth and Environmental Sciences

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Snow and Ice Data Center

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: During the last glacial period atmospheric carbon dioxide and temperature in Antarctica varied in a similar fashion on millennial time scales, but previous work indicates that these changes were gradual. In a detailed analysis of one event, we now find that approximately half of the CO2 increase that occurred during the 1500 year cold period between Dansgaard-Oeschger (DO) Events 8 and 9 happened rapidly, over less than two centuries. This rise in CO2 was synchronous with, or slightly later than, a rapid increase of Antarctic temperature inferred from stable isotopes.
